choices.D: Run a sniffer on the web server.
choices.C: Execute another sniffer on FortiGate, this time with the filter "host 10.0.1.10".
choices.B: Capture the traffic using an external sniffer connected to port1.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
Page 451

Selected Answer: A
Correct Answer: A. Execute a debug flow

Selected Answer: A
Correct Answer: A. Execute a debug flow

A. Execute a debug flow.
Correct. Provides detailed packet routing, NAT, and policy analysis to identify the issue.

B. Capture the traffic using an external sniffer connected to port1.
Incorrect. External sniffers are unnecessary; FortiGate tools are sufficient.

C. Execute another sniffer on FortiGate with the filter "host 10.0.1.10".
Incorrect. The current sniffer already captures traffic from 10.0.1.10.

D. Run a sniffer on the web server.
Incorrect. The problem is better diagnosed from FortiGate first before moving to the server.

Selected Answer: A
After running a sniffer, you need to run "diagnose debug flow" to inspect what is happening with the packet
A IS CORRECT

A is correct
A is correct.

questions.question_text:
Refer to the exhibit.
//IMG//

In the network shown in the exhibit, the web client cannot connect to the HTTP web server. The administrator runs the FortiGate built-in sniffer and gets the output shown in the exhibit.
What should the administrator do next, to troubleshoot the problem?

choices.C: Both interfaces must have DHCP enabled
choices.B: Both interfaces must have directly connected routes on the routing table
choices.D: Both interfaces must have IP addresses assigned
choices.A: Both interfaces must have the interface role assigned

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: BD
BD correct

comments.content: Comment on C - You most definitely CAN have the wan interface set as DHCP. If there are remote sites that only have satelite uplinks or LTE, they will usually operate as DHCP servers, and the Fortigates will get their WAN-IP that way. It is best to have static wan-ip's, but it isn't a must.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: BD
A, you should set a role, but is not strictly demanded
B, must exist a connected route
C, you will not have DHCP server in a WAN interface for example
D, not necesarily you need an IP address in the physical interface, but in this case, they are not contempling VLAN usage

Selected Answer: BD
The best answers are B and D. Answer A is true but not mandatory.

Selected Answer: BD
Since it looks like you can't escape roles (LAN, WAN, DMZ, etc), they give you the impression they are mandatory. But they are for organizational or management purposes and do not affect functionality or connectivity. That is why A isn't within the best answer and B and D are.

Selected Answer: AD
D. is correct for sure.

A. should be correct in so far, that an interface role is always choosen, event if using the preselected role

"Set the role setting for the interface. Different settings will be shown or hidden when editing an interface depending on the role ..."
Fortigate Admin Guide

B. is questionable, because the routes are created automatically as soon, as an ip address is configured

Selected Answer: BD
B&D are correct

Selected Answer: BD
B&D answer

Selected Answer: BD
B&D are correct

Selected Answer: AD
A. Both interfaces must have the interface role assigned: Each interface needs a role (like LAN or DMZ) so FortiGate knows how to handle the traffic between networks.

D. Both interfaces must have IP addresses assigned: Without IPs, the interfaces canâ€™t send or receive traffic properly.

As for B (routes in the table), itâ€™s usually automatic, so itâ€™s not something you have to set up manually.
BD correct

questions.question_text:
FortiGate is operating in NAT mode and has two physical interfaces connected to the LAN and DMZ networks respectively.

Which two statements are true about the requirements of connected physical interfaces on FortiGate? (Choose two.)
Which two pieces of information are synchronized between FortiGate HA members? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: BD
BD correct

Selected Answer: BD
DHCP leases and IPSEC security associations

Selected Answer: BD
In an High Availability (HA) cluster, two or more FortiGate devices work together to ensure network operations continue if one device fails. If the primary device fails, another device in the cluster takes over. The synchronization between these devices includes a number of items:

 Firewall policies and objects: All changes made to the firewall policy table, and to any objects that the table refers to, are synchronized.
 Hostname: The hostname of the FortiGate units is also being synchronized to ensure seamless management and logging.
 Other configurations: Other device settings and configurations are also synced, including VPN configurations, routing information, DHCP server settings, and more.

Selected Answer: BD
B & D
B&D answ

Selected Answer: BD
B & D like Carlie said
B and D
